['Flushy eyes: A colloquial term indicating redness or bloodshot appearance in the eyes, often due to irritation from a rushing flow of tears.', 'Watery eyes: This may occur when there is excessive tear production or an eye irritant causing rapid fluid drainage.', "Redness: Rapid water discharge can lead to redness in the eyes, especially if it's due to a stye (hordeolum) caused by blocked oil glands.", 'Dry eyes: In response to rushing tears or insufficient tear production, an individual may experience dry eyes which could be misinterpreted as "rush of water."', 'Blepharitis: An inflammation of the eyelid margins that can cause excessive tearing and a feeling of water rushing from the eye.', 'Epiphora: A condition where there is an overflow of tears due to inadequate drainage or overproduction, often perceived as a "rush."', 'Conjunctivitis: Inflammation of the conjunctiva that can cause watery eyes and sometimes excessive tearing resembling a rush of water.', 'Glaucoma: A group of eye conditions causing increased pressure within the eyeball, potentially leading to rapid drainage or "rush" symptoms in advanced stages.', 'Lacrimation: Excessive tear production that may be perceived as a rushing flow of water from the eyes.', 'Keratoconjunctivitis sicca: Also known as dry eye syndrome, this condition can lead to excessive tearing (rhinorrhea) due to irritation and inflammation.', 'Epiphora-induced keratopathy: The presence of a "rush" or overflowing tears that may cause corneal damage if chronic and untreated.', 'Canaliculitis: Inflammation of the canaliculus, part of the tear drainage system which can result in rushing tears due to impaited fluid flow.', 'Dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR): A surgical procedure performed when there is an obstruction causing a "rush" or overflowing tears and insufficient tear drainage.', 'Punctate keratitis: This refers to multiple tiny erosions on the cornea, which can cause rushing tears as part of its symptoms.', 'Trichiasis: The inward growth of eyelashes that may scratch the eye and lead to excessive tearing or "rush" of fluid.', 'Blepharospasm: Involuntary closure of the eyelids, which can be a reaction to irritation leading to water rushing out upon reopening the eyes.', 'Canaliculus dacryocystitis: An infection or inflammation of the tear canal that may result in abnormal tearing and "rush" symptoms.', 'Conjunctival hyperemia: Excessive redness of the conjunctiva which can be associated with irritated eyes and rushing tears as a secondary effect.', 'Epiphora-induced keratitis: Inflammation of the cornea due to chronic excessive tearing, resembling a "rush" or overflowing eye fluid.', 'Canaliculus stenosis: Narrowing of the tear drainage canal which can cause tears not draining properly and may lead to symptoms similar to a "rush."']
